let the chips fall where they may.idiom_name: let the chips fall where they may

still waters run deep.idiom_meaning: to have passion or furore underneath a calm expressionEND_LINEa placid exterior covering a something that can be dangerousEND_LINEexternal calm does not mean that the situation is safe since there may be a danger under the waterEND_LINEa quiet person may have deep feelings or an interesting personality when one gets to know themEND_LINE
still waters run deep.idiom_examples: Though he rarely speaks in class, still waters run deep.END_LINEShe did not talk to me that day and I knew that something is wrong, still waters run deep.END_LINEHe didn’t express his opinion in the meeting but still waters run deep.END_LINEYou’re usually shy so I did not expect you had so much to say. I guess still waters run deep.END_LINEYou should not talk with that gang, they’re too quiet and still waters can run deep.END_LINE

all and sundry.idiom_meaning: everyoneEND_LINEone and allEND_LINEall the people, collectively and individuallyEND_LINEeverybody without discriminationEND_LINEpeople in generalEND_LINE

the eleventh hour.idiom_meaning: at the very last minute before an eventEND_LINEthe latest moment possible, before it is too lateEND_LINE

time after time.idiom_meaning: to repeat somethingEND_LINEto say or do something over and over againEND_LINEto be repetitiveEND_LINE

a picture is worth a thousand words.idiom_name: a picture is worth a thousand words
a picture is worth a thousand words.idiom_meaning: a picture conveys information more effectively than wordsEND_LINEa picture can tell a story just as well as many wordsEND_LINEusing graphics can convey ideas more effectively than a large number of wordsEND_LINEgraphic illustration conveys stronger messages than wordsEND_LINE
a picture is worth a thousand words.idiom_examples: A good presentation should contain more of graphics and less of text, since a picture is worth a thousand words.END_LINEIn order to effectively convey the health hazards of smoking, a cigarette pack now contains a picture of diseased lungs, instead of just the statutory warning message. A picture is worth a thousand words.END_LINEThe newspaper report carried more pictures of the event than text, since a picture is worth a thousand words.END_LINEIts easier to learn how a machine works from pictures rather than descriptions, since a picture is worth a thousand words.END_LINEIt would be better if you drew out a map with the direction to the place rather than just telling me. A picture is worth a thousand words.END_LINE

armed to the teeth.idiom_meaning: heavily and formidably armed, usually with deadly weaponsEND_LINEfully prepared or equipped (with weapons, arguments and so on)END_LINEcarrying many weaponsEND_LINEto be armed with ammunition strongly for some kind of war or battleEND_LINEWhen you are well organized for entering into a new project, being financially strong to invest in some businessEND_LINE

run for cover.idiom_meaning: to seek shelterEND_LINEhurry to a warm dry placeEND_LINEusually to get out of bad weatherEND_LINEit is also used to describe getting to a safe place when in a war zone or any place that is being bombed or attackedEND_LINEto attempt to guard yourself from a bad situation or from being criticizedEND_LINE
run for cover.idiom_examples: We ran for cover as soon as the storm broke.END_LINEMy dog runs for cover if you shout on it a bit.END_LINEDon’t run for cover now go face your wife and tell her the truth about your relations with that woman.END_LINEMan, I hate my mother-in-law I am running for cover from her.END_LINERemember if your home is attacked by polar bear get in your car and run for cover because you can’t face them.END_LINE

been around.idiom_meaning: (existed) been present and activeEND_LINEto have gained worldly experienceEND_LINEto have seen or experienced several things in one’s lifeEND_LINEto describe life experiencesEND_LINEto denote that one is not easily fooledEND_LINE

burn fingers.idiom_meaning: to bear an unpleasant result of an action that has been taken in the pastEND_LINEusually referred to the loss of moneyEND_LINEis also used as a forewarning by someone who has experienced the same in the pastEND_LINEinjury that is caused due to meddlingEND_LINE

steal thunder.idiom_meaning: take credit for someone else’s workEND_LINEuse someone else’s ideas to their own advantageEND_LINEtake success or praise away from someoneEND_LINEwin praise by pre-emptying or forestall someone else’s attemptEND_LINEto take attention away from someone elseEND_LINE

add fuel to the flames.idiom_meaning: an action, whether verbal or physical that makes a bad situation even worseEND_LINEcause circumstances or dispute to become further excessiveEND_LINEaggravateEND_LINEworsenEND_LINEexacerbateEND_LINE

time flies.idiom_meaning: for a particular phase in life to seem shorter than it really wasEND_LINEto feel like the good part of life is getting over in a speedy mannerEND_LINEto be reminiscing/missing the pastEND_LINEused as a remark that time seems to elapse very fastEND_LINE

rob peter to pay paul.idiom_meaning: to cause harm to one person in order to do good for anotherEND_LINEthe transfer of money or resources that have been set aside for one purpose to anotherEND_LINEto solve a problem in a way that makes another problem worseEND_LINEto discharge one debt only to incur anotherEND_LINE
rob peter to pay paul.idiom_examples: I moved money from the college savings account to my main account so the debit would clear, robbing Peter to pay Paul.END_LINEA “rob Peter to pay Paul” approach is not a sustainable way to handle your finances.END_LINEWhen she borrowed money from one friend to pay her babysitter, she knew that she was robbing Peter to pay Paul.END_LINEMy mother told me to stop using my credit cards to pay my debts because I was just robbing Peter to pay Paul. its a small world.idiom_meaning: meeting someone not expected to be at a certain placeEND_LINEencountering the same people, events, or situations in an unexpected placeEND_LINEsomeone knows a person you knowEND_LINEused to express surprise that events or people at different places are somehow connectedEND_LINEa water-based boat ride located in the Fantasyland area at the various Walt Disney Parks and Resorts worldwideEND_LINE

Well, it’s a small world indeed!END_LINEFancy running into you here. I thought I would never see you again! It’s a small world.END_LINEDo you know my friend from school? Wow, it’s a small world, isn’t it?END_LINEImagine meeting her at the theater last night. It’s a small world.END_LINE

cry over spilt milk.idiom_meaning: to be upset about things that have already been doneEND_LINEto cry about past events that cannot be undoneEND_LINEto dwell pointlessly about a mistake that can no longer be changedEND_LINEto be upset about past misfortunesEND_LINEto feel sorry about something that has already happenedEND_LINE
cry over spilt milk.idiom_examples: While its sad that the results have not been as good as you expected, you should now focus on moving ahead and achieving better results next time; there is no use crying over spilt milk.END_LINEValarie’s car was badly damaged in the accident and he was angry about what had happened, but he soon realized that there was no use crying over spilt milk.END_LINE“Its no use crying over spilt milk – it was a bad investment, the money has been lost and there’s nothing we can do.”END_LINEMona was unable to accept the reality of her divorce. She was crying over spilled milk.END_LINEThe school trip had been a disaster, but we did not want to dwell on it. It was no use crying over spilt milk.END_LINE

in a huff.idiom_meaning: to be upset or angry about somethingEND_LINEbehaving in a bad-tempered way because someone is upsetEND_LINEa fit of angerEND_LINEslang for someone who is sulking about somethingEND_LINEin an offended wayEND_LINE
in a huff.idiom_examples: June was very upset because her mother would not buy her a new pair of shoes, so she stormed out of the room in a huff.END_LINEAlice is in a huff because her best friend promised to go out with her, but at the last minute she had to cancel.END_LINEMy inability to make up my mind about where I want to go for supper has put my husband in a huff, I think that I will have to make a decision quickly, otherwise I will go hungry.END_LINEI am still in a huff because you forgot my birthday, I can’t believe you didn’t remember.END_LINEI am sorry that I am in a huff today, the coffee shop was out of my favourite tea this morning.END_LINE

pass the buck.idiom_meaning: passing blame to another personEND_LINEshift the responsibility for something to someone elseEND_LINEappoint someone else to be in charge of somethingEND_LINEhold someone accountable for a situation that has to be addressedEND_LINEblame somebody or to make others responsible for a problem that you should deal with yourselfEND_LINE
pass the buck.idiom_examples: That particular supervisor tends to pass the buck of all light duties to newly hired interns.END_LINEWhenever she has a new house help, she always takes time to know and train her before passing the buck.END_LINEUpon realizing the number of assignments given to him, the class representative passed the buck to the other group leaders.END_LINEAlthough it was hard for everyone, including himself, the Vice-chancellor had no choice but to pass the buck to the deputy vice-chancellor.END_LINEDue to the COVID-19 pandemic, most of the restaurants in Sydney have been forced to cut down their staff and pass the buck to a few remaining employees.END_LINE

foam at the mouth.idiom_meaning: be extremely angryEND_LINEbe enraged and show itEND_LINEshow uncontrollable angerEND_LINEdisplay furious rageEND_LINE
foam at the mouth.idiom_examples: She was foaming at the mouth when she heard of her child’s misdeeds.END_LINEHe was foaming at the mouth when he realized that important papers had been stolen from his office.END_LINEThe boss was foaming at the mouth when the team could not deliver the work on time.END_LINEHe was foaming at the mouth when he heard about the cost of repairing the damage.END_LINEShe was foaming at the mouth when she heard that the decision had gone against her.END_LINE

love at first sight.idiom_meaning: strong and immediate attraction to someone you have just metEND_LINElove established when two people meet for the first timeEND_LINEinstant attraction for someone or somethingEND_LINEfall in love with a person the first time you see themEND_LINE
love at first sight.idiom_examples: For Sarah and Samuel, it was love at first sight, and they have now decided to get married.END_LINEI had met my wife at a friend’s party, and it was love at first sight for us.END_LINEThough it was love at first sight for Tracy and John, it did not last long and they broke up after just six months.END_LINEIt had been love at first sight for my friend and his wife, and even after all these years they are still like newlyweds.END_LINEThey had met at a business conference as representatives of rival companies, but it had been love at first sight and they ended up as partners.END_LINE

under the auspices.idiom_meaning: under the protection, sponsorship, or patronageEND_LINEunder the oversight, supervision, control of managementEND_LINEwith help, support, or approvalEND_LINEwith the backing, or patronage ofEND_LINE
under the auspices.idiom_examples: We restored the home under the auspices of the historical society.END_LINEWe learned our acting craft under the auspices of our director.END_LINEThe symphony played under the auspices of their conductor.END_LINEShe learned French under the auspices of her tutor.END_LINEFinancial aid is being provided to the country under the auspices of the World Bank.END_LINE

actions speak louder than words.idiom_meaning: what you do carries more weight than what you sayEND_LINEdoing is better than just speakingEND_LINEyour actions are more significant than your wordsEND_LINEbetter to do something rather than just talkEND_LINE
actions speak louder than words.idiom_examples: “You always speak of the importance of charity, but never do anything. beyond a shadow of doubt.idiom_meaning: to be certain about something’s validityEND_LINEto be true or legitimateEND_LINEto be (something) without any doubt about itEND_LINEindubitablyEND_LINE

so and so.idiom_meaning: Used in the place of someone’s name, indicating that the person is of little importanceEND_LINEUsed in place of a person or thing when you are speaking generallyEND_LINEIt can also be used as euphemism to describe an unpleasant personEND_LINECan be used in place of a swear wordEND_LINE
so and so.idiom_examples: I love how June is always telling us how she met so-and-so on her travels. Everyone knows that she is making it up.END_LINEBook club is mostly used for gossiping. when in rome do as the romans.idiom_name: when in rome do as the romans
when in rome do as the romans.idiom_meaning: to copy popular culture in order to blend inEND_LINErespect and follow the custom of the native people while visiting their land to get favourEND_LINEit’s good to follow the local customs for visitorEND_LINE
when in rome do as the romans.idiom_examples: My mother always told us that when in Rome, do as the Romans. take a hike.idiom_meaning: go awayEND_LINEget lostEND_LINEleaveEND_LINEget outEND_LINEa rude/slang way of saying I/we don’t want you aroundEND_LINE
take a hike.idiom_examples: We’re all sick of you saying the same things over and over again. Why don’t you just take a hike?END_LINEYou’re not helping the situation with your overcritical attitude. time and again.idiom_meaning: to be repeated very oftenEND_LINEto happen again and againEND_LINEover and over againEND_LINE

eat like a horse.idiom_meaning: to eat a lotEND_LINEto have a very healthy appetiteEND_LINEto eat voraciously, greedily, quickly, hungrily, maybe even savagelyEND_LINEto devour food like an animalEND_LINEto enjoy your food a little too muchEND_LINE

I’ll have to go on a diet after the New Year.END_LINE

apple polisher.idiom_meaning: a flatterer; toadyEND_LINEa person who tries to get favours from those in authority through flatteryEND_LINEa person who seeks for promotion or rewards from higher ups by singing their praises or complimenting themEND_LINEa person who mostly says false things to those in authority in order to get something in returnEND_LINE

sitting duck.idiom_meaning: to be an easy targetEND_LINEto be in a vulnerable position to be attackedEND_LINE

cross paths.idiom_meaning: encounter or meet someone by chanceEND_LINEunexpectedly come across somebodyEND_LINEThe idiom is used to express a general encounter or meeting with someone, especially when it was not expectedEND_LINEIt is used to describe being in the same physical place with someone else by pure chance, maybe in the street, a show, a restaurant, or any other random location, especially when the meeting occurred because of two separate journeysEND_LINE

the items that cannot be compared with each
otherEND_LINEan unfair comparisonEND_LINEtwo things that belong to different classesEND_LINEthings that are completely differentEND_LINEpossessing non-identical attributesEND_LINE

a rolling stone gathers no moss.idiom_examples: It was time for you to settle down at least five years back. you know better than that.idiom_meaning: used to express disappointment when someone makes a mistake which they probably shouldn’t haveEND_LINEused to show disapproval of someone’s actionsEND_LINE
you know better than that.idiom_examples: She told me that you abused her, you know better than that.END_LINEYou know better than that. Make sure you do not make the same mistake again. “Son replied arrogantly,”Okay, is that all.”END_LINETed said, “I think I should go for this night out with them because I am sure it will be a lot of fun. “His mom replied,” I’m sure you know better than that. It is your wish though.”END_LINE

on demand.idiom_meaning: when neededEND_LINEwhen asked forEND_LINEto ask for with the proper rightEND_LINEclaim as a rightEND_LINEat any time that you want or need somethingEND_LINE

at the drop of a hat.idiom_name: at the drop of a hat

piece of cake.idiom_meaning: very easy taskEND_LINEsomething easily doneEND_LINEvery simple workEND_LINEeffortlessly prepared or doneEND_LINEsimple job that can straightforwardly be accomplishedEND_LINE

blood is thicker than water.idiom_meaning: family relations and bonds are closer than other relationshipsEND_LINEpeople who are related have stronger bonds with each other than with othersEND_LINEblood relations are more important than other kinds of relationsEND_LINE
blood is thicker than water.idiom_examples: When you get into trouble, usually your family will be the ones to bail you out, not your friends. Blood is thicker than water, you know.END_LINEI had to choose between attending my cousin’s and friend’s wedding, which were on the same day, and I chose my cousin’s. thats the way the cookie crumbles.idiom_name: thats the way the cookie crumbles

unring the bell.idiom_meaning: once something has been done you cannot run away from it, you can only face the aftermathEND_LINEramifications have to be withstood whenever something is doneEND_LINEwe cannot take back something once said or doneEND_LINE
unring the bell.idiom_examples: Remember Tom, you cannot unring the bell once you have sent out that mail.END_LINEOnce he was done screaming at his old parents for all the pain they had caused him, he realized that there was no unringing the bell now.END_LINEIt often happens to me that I say some really awful things to my mother even though I love her and I realize that there is no unringing the bell now.END_LINEIf only we could unring the bell, this world would be a better place to live in.END_LINEYou can only learn from the mistakes that you make and not repeat them again because unringing the bell is not an option.END_LINE

spare someones blushes.idiom_meaning: to stop someone from feeling awkward or embarrassedEND_LINEto stop someone from being humiliated by a situation or circumstanceEND_LINEto stop someone from saying or doing something embarrassingEND_LINEto help someone avoid feeling awkward about doing or saying something uncomfortableEND_LINEsaving someone from doing something cringeworthyEND_LINE

deals with.idiom_meaning: be concerned with somethingEND_LINEto take action about somethingEND_LINEto handle someone or somethingEND_LINE

over and over again.idiom_meaning: again and againEND_LINEsomething happening in frequent intervalsEND_LINEto do something multiple timesEND_LINE

leaps and bounds.idiom_meaning: progress very quicklyEND_LINEgrow or increase rapidlyEND_LINEget better or improve in a short timeEND_LINE

heart and soul.idiom_meaning: with all the effort you can put into itEND_LINEwith sincerity and commitmentEND_LINEthe whole of one’s obsession and energyEND_LINEthe essence, spirit or coreEND_LINEwith complete honesty and loyaltyEND_LINE
heart and soul.idiom_examples: He’s dedicated to the project heart and soul.END_LINEShe’s thrown herself heart and soul into her studies.END_LINEIf you put your heart and soul into your training you will make it.END_LINEI feel so sorry for the team. no news is good news.idiom_meaning: to assume that since there is no news, it will not be bad newsEND_LINEto not know the outcome of something and hence believe that it is good newsEND_LINEto be sure that when it is bad news, it will be made known, which means that in the meanwhile, there is no bad newsEND_LINE
no news is good news.idiom_examples: The exam results are not yet out and I feel no news is good news.END_LINEYou should call your mom and check about her health even though you think no news is good news.END_LINEShe had said she will text me when she knows about the outcome and until then, I am going to go for a vacation because no news is good news.END_LINEIn this business, no news is good news.END_LINEYou will have to wait until we can hear back from the embassy about your visa but in the meanwhile, no news is good news.END_LINE

on a silver platter.idiom_meaning: to get something without having to work for itEND_LINEto receive something without having to put in much effortEND_LINEpresenting something in a formal fashionEND_LINE
on a silver platter.idiom_examples: She has never had to work a day in her life. clarion call.idiom_meaning: A clarion is a high-pitch bugleEND_LINEA strong and clear request for people to do somethingEND_LINEIn a literal sense, the call to battle is issued by such an instrument END_LINEUsed in the figurative sense, a call to take up a task or pursue a projectEND_LINEThe idiom metaphorically ascribes the characteristics of a bugle to a spoken command or statement, indicating that it was issued loudly and clearly END_LINE
clarion call.idiom_examples: All of the citizens heard the clarion call and prepared themselves to defend their city. END_LINEWhen I heard that my mother had decided not to go to the party, I issued a clarion call to my brothers and sisters; subsequently, they convinced her to attend.END_LINEThe clarion call for additional donations from social leaders has elicited a swift reaction.END_LINE

END_LINEI have not offered you more because beggars can’t be choosers.END_LINEYour brother living with us cannot ask for more things to be stocked in his room since beggars can’t be choosers.END_LINEYou asked for this and now you want me to exchange it? Don’t you know that beggars can’t be choosers?END_LINE

bite off more than can chew.idiom_name: bite off more than can chew
bite off more than can chew.idiom_meaning: try to do more than one is able to doEND_LINEundertake a promise one cannot accomplishEND_LINEattempt to do something which is hardly achievableEND_LINEto start or promise something to do more than one can accomplishEND_LINE

wet behind the ears.idiom_meaning: immature or poor skillEND_LINEto be inexperiencedEND_LINEto be new at something or somewhere and so lack the necessary experienceEND_LINE

a quick buck.idiom_meaning: to make money quicklyEND_LINEto make money in a dishonest mannerEND_LINEto earn money quickly and fast, usually in an unethical wayEND_LINEto earn an amount of money by completing a favour for another individualEND_LINEan offer to help someone make money quickly for taking on a jobEND_LINE
a quick buck.idiom_examples: He decided to make a quick buck by selling his CD collection.END_LINEIt was a fast buck scheme that ended up costing people a lot of money.END_LINEMaking a quick buck can help people to pay their bills when they need to.END_LINEPeople will look to make a fast buck when they need something.END_LINEJack is trying to make a fast buck by selling burgers on a busy street.END_LINE

wouldnt be caught dead.idiom_meaning: dislike something very muchEND_LINEwould never do something, usually due to dislike or because it is very embarrassingEND_LINEwould rather die than do somethingEND_LINE

She wouldn’t be caught dead hanging out with him.END_LINEHe values his job a lot and wouldn’t be caught dead going against the company’s directive.END_LINE

love rat.idiom_meaning: someone, usually a man, who has a secret affair while being in a relationshipEND_LINEa man who betrays, or is unfaithful to his wife or girlfriendEND_LINEa man who cheats on his partnerEND_LINEa man who has had a secret sexual relationship with someone who is not his regular partnerEND_LINEa man who commits adultery or is promiscuousEND_LINE
love rat.idiom_examples: I heard Bill had an affair with his wife’s best friend! What a love rat he is!END_LINEHe’s had affairs with numerous women while still being married to her. He’s a complete love rat.END_LINEWhen it was discovered that the star footballer was having an affair with another woman while his wife was expecting, the press had a field time cashing in on the scandal and calling him a love rat.END_LINEYou are already in a relationship, why do you want to ask another woman out for a date? Don’t be a love rat.END_LINEWhen the popular minister’s adulterous relationships were revealed, his political career came crashing down. accidentally on purpose.idiom_meaning: performing an action intentionally and pretending to either oneself or to the world that as an accidentEND_LINEas if by accident, but really by meaningEND_LINE
accidentally on purpose.idiom_examples: I hate this flower vase so much, some day I might drop it accidentally on purpose.END_LINEDespite being so brilliant, how did he failed. I suspect he flunked accidentally on purposeEND_LINEShe didn’t want to have any contact with him. So she deleted his phone number accidentally on purposeEND_LINEIt seems Richard did not wanted to wear that shirt so he spilled ketchup over it accidentally on purposeEND_LINEThere was no way those two met by coincidence. He was stalking her to meet accidentally on purpose.END_LINE

double take.idiom_meaning: to be so surprised at something that you have to take another look (American meaning)END_LINEa delayed reaction to something (British meaning)END_LINEIt can be accompanied by a sudden movement of the head in order to take another lookEND_LINE
double take.idiom_examples: I did a double take when I saw how much weight my best friend had lost.END_LINEWhen the new car entered the parking lot everyone did a double take.END_LINEKeanu Reeves would typically be easy to pick out in a crowd, but his new appearance can make just about anyone do a double take. Daniela Sternitzky-Di Napoli, Houston Chronicle, “Keanu Reeves spotted looking like Forrest Gump at an event in Italy.”END_LINE“I just looked up and that’s when I spotted the flickering in the water.” “It looked as though the light was bouncing off something but there were no boats or people and it was something long – very long.” “I had to do a double take because there was just nothing to explain it.”END_LINE

level playing field.idiom_meaning: a situation that is fair to everyoneEND_LINEwhere everyone gets the same opportunityEND_LINEa situation where everyone has an equal and fair chance of succeedingEND_LINEa fair competition, where no advantage is shown to one sideEND_LINE

blind spot.idiom_meaning: if you have a blind spot about something, you cannot accept or understand itEND_LINEa subject about which one is ignorant or biasedEND_LINEan area in which one fails to exercise judgment or discriminationEND_LINEa portion of a field that cannot be seen or observed with existing equipmentEND_LINEthe part of the road that you cannot see when driving a car (not even in the mirror)END_LINE
blind spot.idiom_examples: Please don’t point out my “blind spots” to me; I would rather find them on my own.END_LINEJim’s inability to feel any empathy for his co-workers was a blind spot that cost him his promotion.END_LINEI had no idea that I was being so critical until my partner called me out on my blind spot.END_LINESally always seems to have a blind spot when it comes to men; she can’t seem to see the red flags until it’s too late.END_LINEThe company’s lack of response to the customer complaint was a major blind spot that contributed to its downfall.END_LINE

back to the wall.idiom_meaning: to be in a difficult situationEND_LINEto have the odds against one’s selfEND_LINEto have no way of being able to get awayEND_LINEto have no space to escapeEND_LINEto be caught by someone without having an easy escape routeEND_LINE

green thumb.idiom_meaning: good gardening resultsEND_LINEsuccess or skill in growing plants/seedsEND_LINEnatural ability to grow thingsEND_LINE
green thumb.idiom_examples: My mother has green fingers. She can grow just about anything in the garden.END_LINEPete has really taken to gardening in his retirement. a dime a dozen.idiom_meaning: something very common and not having much valueEND_LINEsomething that is abundant, cheap and very commonEND_LINEsomething that is very common and not of much valueEND_LINEso plentiful as to be valuelessEND_LINEsomething that is easily acquiredEND_LINE

save your breath.idiom_meaning: to not waste effort on something that has no outcomeEND_LINErefraining from a futile effortEND_LINEavoid explaining or advising someone when it has no impactEND_LINEit is useless talking to someone who does not listenEND_LINE

roots run deep.idiom_meaning: similar in meaning to “deep-rooted”END_LINEused to indicate that an attribute (of a person, institution, or other entity) has a rich and complex origin, which makes it stable and unlikely to changeEND_LINEcan be used to indicate the profound historical, social, or cultural influence on a personEND_LINErelatedly, it can be used to indicate that a quality or feature that seems to have been eliminated will likely reappear (Analogous to how a weed will grow back unless it is removed by the root)END_LINEin genealogical and familial contexts, it is often used to indicate that an interest, concern, or quality has been shared or developed over many generationsEND_LINE

turn the tables.idiom_meaning: change your position with respect to someone elseEND_LINEturning an unfavorable circumstance into one of favorEND_LINEto make one’s plan turn back on themEND_LINEcausing one’s plans to be reversedEND_LINE

I should have known she is smart enough to turn the tables.END_LINEThe businessman who was on the verge of bankruptcy turned the tables when he won a million dollar in casino with a few thousands he had.END_LINEThe activist held a seminar for people to turn the tables in government employees who ask for bribery.END_LINEAria who had been accused of infringement by her competitor, turned the tables on him by presenting the proof of her innocence at the last moment.END_LINEIt is easy to turn the tables against your rival. You just have to act witty & know their weakness.END_LINE

mull over.idiom_meaning:
to take a long time to make a
decisionEND_LINEto spend a large amount of time
considering ones options before making a decisionEND_LINEto think sincerely about somethingEND_LINEthink overEND_LINEconsiderEND_LINE
mull over.idiom_examples: I will need to mull things over before I decide whether or not to start my own business. It is a big decision.END_LINEYou should mull over getting back to your ex again.END_LINEI am mulling over the expansion of my business to overseas.END_LINEYou have been mulling things over for weeks now, if you don’t give them an answer soon, they will employ someone else.END_LINEMy friend is mulling over the idea of adopting a baby.END_LINE

happy wife happy life.idiom_meaning: to have a good life, you need to have a good wifeEND_LINEwhen the wife in a family is happy, she can help her husband in their home to be satisfiedEND_LINEif a wife is happy in her marriage, the husband is also happy, and consequently has a delighted lifeEND_LINE
happy wife happy life.idiom_examples: The first time I heard the phrase “happy wife, happy life,” I was a small person in college and found it very pleasant.END_LINEMy husband has been a delighted person, and she has been using the phrase “happy wife, happy life” to describe me when we are in the company.END_LINEI am planning to gift my wife an iPhone because I believe happy wife happy life.END_LINE

back to square one.idiom_meaning: return to where one started fromEND_LINEback to the beginningEND_LINEreturn to the starting point, start all over againEND_LINEstart again from the beginning because previous attempt failedEND_LINE
back to square one.idiom_examples: The Government and the State Bank spent years strengthening the nation’s economy but the recession and slowdown shattered it, so we are back to square one.END_LINEHaving tried to solve the problem for quite some time, we were back to square one when none of our solutions worked.END_LINEThe local authorities had repaired the roads a few month ago, but heavy rains damaged them again, so we are back to square one.END_LINEThe opposing parties had been trying to come to a compromise, but when the negotiations broke down, they were back to square one.END_LINEThe police haven’t made any breakthroughs in solving the crime. Their investigation led them to a dead end, so now they are back to square one.END_LINE

hang in there.idiom_meaning: wait, be patient till things work outEND_LINEdon’t give upEND_LINEbe persistent in face of difficultiesEND_LINEkeep tryingEND_LINE

let your heart rule your head.idiom_name: let your heart rule your head
let your heart rule your head.idiom_meaning: do something based on emotions rather than logicEND_LINEact according to what you feel rather than what is sensibleEND_LINEdo something because you want to, rather than for practical reasonsEND_LINElet your emotions control your sense of reasoningEND_LINE
let your heart rule your head.idiom_examples: I think it would be unwise for you to be in a relationship with him; he is a known womanizer. Don’t let your heart rule your head.END_LINEI know he is not rich and does not have much social status, but he loves you and cares for you a lot, so for this one time, I would say let your heart rule your head; you’ll be glad you did.END_LINEMost romantic movies and stories paint this rosy picture about love and tell you that all will be well if you let your heart rule your head, but the reality is quite the opposite in most cases.END_LINEI had warned him that he would suffer if he let his heart rule his head, but he was too enamoured by her charm then; and now that she’s left him, he’s completely broken.END_LINESometimes, it pays off to ignore all logic and let your heart rule your head.END_LINE

riddle me.idiom_meaning: a catchphrase used to introduce a joke, observation, question, or riddleEND_LINEmaking a demand of a listener to note a situation about to be mentioned or a question, mostly ones that are hard to explain or solveEND_LINEposing a challenge to a person to answer a question with no apparent answerEND_LINEused to sarcastically or humorously pay emphasis to a question, undercutting the self-assuredness of another personEND_LINEa rhetorical way of questioning conventional wisdomEND_LINE
riddle me.idiom_examples: Despite acting so confidently, riddle me this: how will we get all that money within a day?END_LINEHow will you pay for all your plans if you quit your job? Riddle me that.END_LINERiddle me this: why was such a talented collective so horrible in their work?END_LINE

go through a rough patch.idiom_meaning: to experience a lot of problems in a period of lifeEND_LINEbe in the middle of a period of troubleEND_LINEexperience a difficult or unpleasant period of timeEND_LINEto face a lot of hardships during a period of timeEND_LINE
go through a rough patch.idiom_examples: They have usually been very supportive of each other, but right now, their marriage is going through a bit of a rough patch.END_LINESteve has been going through a rough patch lately – he has lost his job and his wife wants a divorce.END_LINEAll relationships go through a rough patch at some point or the other. The key is to work together to resolve the issues and not blame each other for what’s gone wrong.END_LINEThey are going through a bit of a rough patch at the moment, but I am sure they will get over it soon and work out a way to settle their differences.END_LINETheir marriage went through a rough patch when he quit his job to try his hand at something new, but now, they love each other more than ever.END_LINE

bon appetit.idiom_meaning: enjoy your meal/foodEND_LINEliterally translates to “good appetite”END_LINEI hope that you have a hearty (healthy) appetite for this foodEND_LINEI wish you pleasure in eating this foodEND_LINEa way of wishing your fellow diners to have a good eating experienceEND_LINE
bon appetit.idiom_examples: I want to thank you all for coming to my dinner party, and I’d like to wish you all bon appetit!END_LINEIt is polite to say something like “bon appetit” or “enjoy!” before sharing a meal with others.END_LINEHere is your dinner, Darling. Bon appetit!END_LINESally dear – please serve our guests their food, and wish them bon appetit.END_LINEI know that we’re all excited to be here and to have the chance to once again enjoy the pleasure of Maria’s home cooking. So without further ado, I will wish us all bon appetit, and please ask if there is anything further that you need.END_LINE

cock and bull story.idiom_meaning: complicated, ridiculous, or unbelievable storyEND_LINEa story or explanation which is obviously not trueEND_LINEan unbelievable and fanciful storyEND_LINEa far fetched or implausible tale, used as an explanation or excuseEND_LINEan exaggerated or falsified storyEND_LINE
